dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, uh, Host_B, you've seen the news coming out of Hong Kong, right? There's this app, Bridgefy, that's just seen download numbers absolutely *spike* because of the current political crisis.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, uh, Host B, you've seen the news coming out of Hong Kong, right? There's this app, Bridgefy, that's just seen download numbers absolutely spike because of the current political crisis.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As Forbes reported earlier this week, the app has seen download numbers spike due to the political crisis in the city

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's pretty fascinating. It's almost become the de facto offline messaging app, replacing Firechat, which, you know, was big during the 2014 protests.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's pretty fascinating. It's almost become the de facto offline messaging app, replacing Firechat, which, you know, was big during the twenty fourteen protests.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: it appears to have become the de facto offline messaging app replacing Firechat, which became popular during the 2014 pro-democracy protests.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right. But for those who don't know, like, how does it actually *work*? Because it's not using cell towers or the internet, is it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. But for those who don't know, like, how does it actually work? Because it's not using cell towers or the internet, is it?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Nope, not at all! It uses what's called a mesh network. So, uh, smartphones connect directly to each other via short-range Bluetooth. They form their own network, completely independent of carrier cell masts or Wi-Fi.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Nope, not at all! It uses what's called a mesh network. So, uh, smartphones connect directly to each other via short-range Bluetooth. They form their own network, completely independent of carrier cell masts or Wi-Fi.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As with Firechat, Bridgefy uses a mesh network. That means smartphones use short-range Bluetooth connections to form their own network independent of the carrier cell masts and the internet.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, I see. So, that's why it'd be super difficult for, say, authorities in Hong Kong or China to shut it down?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, I see. So, that's why it'd be super difficult for, say, authorities in Hong Kong or China to shut it down?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! There's no single point of failure. Messages can just hop from device to device across the network. There's no central server for police to target.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! There's no single point of failure. Messages can just hop from device to device across the network. There's no central server for police to target.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: There is no single point of failure that police could target to shut Bridgefy down.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Sounds, uh, almost too good to be true, though. There's gotta be a catch, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Sounds, uh, almost too good to be true, though. There's gotta be a catch, right?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, for sure, Host_A. There are some pretty significant risks. For instance, police could actually *sign up* to Bridgefy themselves.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, for sure, Host A. There are some pretty significant risks. For instance, police could actually sign up to Bridgefy themselves.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For instance, police could sign up to Bridgefy and, at the very least, cause confusion by flooding the network with fake broadcasts.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] And, like, flood the network with fake broadcasts? Setting traps for protestors or causing panic?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And, like, flood the network with fake broadcasts? Setting traps for protestors or causing panic?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Imagine a flurry of messages telling protestors to organize in a particular location, one where authorities are lying in wait. Or a message that caused panic by saying officials were violently shutting down protests in a certain location.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Precisely. Imagine messages telling people to gather in a spot where authorities are just waiting. And then there are the security and privacy concerns that Matthew Green, an expert from Johns Hopkins, highlighted.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Precisely. Imagine messages telling people to gather in a spot where authorities are just waiting. And then there are the security and privacy concerns that Matthew Green, an expert from Johns Hopkins, highlighted.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Matthew Green, associate professor at the Johns Hopkins Information Security Institute, downloaded the app to review its security and privacy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right, like how can you really trust the identity of the person you're communicating with when it's all offline? Confidentiality.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, like how can you really trust the identity of the person you're communicating with when it's all offline? Confidentiality.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: How can users be sure of the identity of the person with whom theyre communicating?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Bridgefy *does* claim they use end-to-end RSA encryption for private and mesh messages. So that's something.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Bridgefy does claim they use end-to-end R S A encryption for private and mesh messages. So that's something.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We use end-to-end RSA encryption on private direct and mesh messaging, the spokesperson said (RSA is a well-known cryptographic standard).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But, um, they also admit broadcast messages are purposefully *not* encrypted. And even with encryption, they say no app is bulletproof.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But, um, they also admit broadcast messages are purposefully not encrypted. And even with encryption, they say no app is bulletproof.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Broadcast messages are purposefully not encrypted, so everyone can read them. The spokesperson admitted, though, that no app can be bulletproof from snooping.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, their own terms and conditions state that your content is subject to interception. So, uh, that's a big red flag.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, their own terms and conditions state that your content is subject to interception. So, uh, that's a big red flag.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Indeed, in the companys terms and conditions, Bridgefy notes: No security measure is 100% reliable and your content is subject to interception by third parties unaffiliated with Bridgefy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And what about metadata? Green also brought up how device identifiers could be collected.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And what about metadata? Green also brought up how device identifiers could be collected.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Green also highlighted concerns about collection of metadata, especially if some people running the app are also police. That metadata could include a Bridgefy users mobile phone device identifier.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Which could potentially be used to identify users via, like, government requests to phone carriers. Or even by looking at what other apps you have.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which could potentially be used to identify users via, like, government requests to phone carriers. Or even by looking at what other apps you have.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That could then be used to determine the identity of the owner of the cellphonevia a government request from the carrier, for instance.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Like Tencent being forced to hand over lists of WeChat users running similar apps. That's a huge privacy invasion.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Like Tencent being forced to hand over lists of WeChat users running similar apps. That's a huge privacy invasion.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Chinas government could simply demand Tencent hand over a list of users running the app and where theyre located.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And we can't forget the threat of malware, too. Malicious links spread through broadcasts could, um, really compromise devices.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And we can't forget the threat of malware, too. Malicious links spread through broadcasts could, um, really compromise devices.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Theres also the threat of a government spreading malware via the app with broadcasts pushing malicious links.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, while Bridgefy offers incredible utility for communication in extreme situations...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, while Bridgefy offers incredible utility for communication in extreme situations...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: ...it comes with some truly serious risks that anyone using it needs to be fully aware of. It's a real double-edged sword.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: ...it comes with some truly serious risks that anyone using it needs to be fully aware of. It's a real double-edged sword.
